bibl.title: Letter from W.F. de Niedman to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 4, 1928

div1.p: De Niedman offers his recollections of yellow fever work in Cuba, including investigations of Sanarelli's bacillus and sanitary measures undertaken.

div1.head: Letter from W.F. de Niedman to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 4, 1928
div1.opener:
Los Altos, California
April 4th 1928.
Colonel J. R. Kean
U. S. Army.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Colonel:
div1.p:
Wonder, if upon the receipt of this you
would say: Here he is again? You would be in the
right to say this, for no busy man wishes to be
interrupted upon any and every flimsy provocation
or pretext.- I wish to thank you for the kind
offer to assist me in processing another Badge
of the Association of Military Surgeons of U. S. to replace
one carelessly misplaced or lost. After reading
your kind note, offering assistance to procure
another Badge, my family decided to make
another diligent search for the one lost, and so,
I am living in the expectation and hope that their
effort might be successful. But, in addition
to expressing my many thanks for your ever kindness,
these exist on other cause why I wanted to write to you:
The other day, when picking up the March number
of the Military Surgeon, the very first article that
greeted my eyes, was one from your pen on
“The Dedication of the Birthplace of Walter Reed”.-
In reading this article many old memories of the
days of 1898 came to life again, particularly of the
period when I had the pleasure to serve under you
in Pinar del Rio, Cuba:
2
How well I am reminded of your constant
kindness and consideration, as my Chief at
Quemados, during the many vexations and trobles and
days there.- In one of my letters, quite a while
ago, I casually asked you, if you did not desire
to learn of other things that I was doing at
Pinar del Rio, in addition to routine duties in
connection with my hospital and command.
Not hearing from you on this subject, I hesitated
to speak, fearing that the subject matter would
not be of interest to you. However, on reading
your March article, so many incidents of my
service in 1898 were forcibly brought to my mind,
that I could not resist the temptation to let you know
something about them.- On the page at 298 of your
article reference is made to the study of Bacillus
ichteroides by the Yellow Fever Board and of the
experiments of Wasdin and Giddings of the Public
Health Service of the U.S. with the Sanarelli serum
as a preventitive agent against Yellow Fever etc
giving also the Reed Board findings,-
A great deal of this, in a great measure, coincided,
paralleled or interlocked, as it were, with some individual
observations and efforts made by me and a corps of Cuban
medical civilian practitioners while in Pinar del Rio.-
I desire to preface this statement, about this particular
experiment made in Cuba, by an other, and that is,
that for two years or even longer, prior to the outbrake
3
3
2.
of the War with Spain I had the honor to hold
the appointment of Chairman of Cuban League
in the State of Kansas, collecting funds and medical
supplies, forwarding these to Cuba via the Liegue
Headquarters in New York. In this manner, I came
naturally in possession of many important facts
concerning conditions in Cuba. At that time I was
also the ranking Surgeon of the Natl. Guard of the
State of Kansas, and so thoroughly became I convinced
that War with Spain was almost inevitable that
I began to study Spanish and prepare myself by
careful and systematic study both, of the Typhoid
and the yellow fever. In this effort I was greatly assisted
by General Geo. M. Sternberg the Surgeon General U. S. Army,
who, not only aided one with books and periodicals on
these subjects, but enabled me to procure, through
friends in Paris, France, a number of publications
on the subject of Yellow Fever in the Antilles.
In fall of 1898, while commanding the Corps Reserve Hospital
and the 1st Division Hospital 2d Army Corps at Camp Meade
near Harrisburg Pa. I met Major Walter Reed us.a
who was then on an inspection tour of Hospitals
in connection with Typhoid fever investigation. He was
accompanied by a Russian Military Medical Representative,
Both of these officers expressed their agreeable surprise
at the conditions they found in my hospital as
compared with those recently inspected in the South.
4
4
Shortly thereafter I was ordered to equip and
organize the 3d Division Hospital 2d Army Corps
with orders following to proceed to Cuba, via Athens Ga
and Savannah Ga. While loading our Medical
Supplies on the US. Transport Minnewaska at Savannah,
Major Evelin Pilcher M. C. US. Army turned over to me
in person a number of cases containing Sanarelli
serum, and with these were explicit instructions
from General Geo. M. Sternberg, Surgeon General of the Army,
to give this serum a full and thorough test in any
and all available cases of Yellow Fever, making
full exhaustive records, submitting these records
direct, to him, when proper time presented,
upon arrival and while getting established at Pinar
del Rio, Cuba- I found there, only one Cuban case
of Yellow Fever, convalescing, in the so called
“Casa del Salud”, the Spanish Pest House, and
during my entire period of service at Pinar,
we did not have a single case of Yellow Fever
among our troops on duty there, but there were
sporadic cases reported and treated in the provice
among the native population. For this reason
I had no opportunity to try out Senarelli serum
among the members of our own command.
Fortunately, with the assistance of Major Wm. L. Kneeder,
M. C. US. Army (Coronado Calif) - we succeeded to organize
a Medical Society of Cuban Civil. Practitioners in Pinar
and the Provice proper, and these men, under
5
3.
leadership of Drs Ramos and Avendani D.
were liberally supplied with experimental material
using it in every known case of yellow fever under
my instructions and supervision, furnishing complete
reports for verification and tabulation. In this
manner was I enabled to follow up these cases,
study them carefully and note the effect of
Sanarelli serum as a curative and preventative agent
on May 25- 1899, by G. O.# 23, Hdqrs. Military District No 1
Pinar del Rio Cuba, I was appointed in addition
to all other duties, as Health Officer of that District
and this authority greatly strengthened my hands,
more so, as it carried also the approval of the Civil
Governor of the Province. Of course, this work
added responsibility, worry and sleepless nights
to my other duties- I was kept very busy.
You may recollect also, that at an earlier period
of my service in Pinar del Rio. I had the good
fortune to break up successfully an incipient
epidemic of Typhoid fever, - it was strenious work,
I am almost sure to believe, that at that particular
period you had no information, that I was also
experimenting and testing out Sanarelli serum,
but my friend Major Wm L. Kneedler know well
that I was doing considerable microscopic and
laboratory work, using Widel's agglutination test as well as
and trying to demonstrate the Seidelin bodies in blood,
smears taken from yellow fever patients, under all manner
of difficulties by staining.
6
6
Major Kneedler knew also of many of my preventive
measures adopted and carried out. One will
I had never to admit a case of fever, at once, into
our Field or Pavilion hospitals until, a thorough
examination was made and determined excluding
all chances admitting yellow fever.- Mosquito
Bars were used by the entire command, even
the Guard house was supplied with them, and a
nightly inspection of all sleeping quarters was
made in enforcing this regulation- You see,
it was only the carrying out of your kind
admonition to me that "Ethernal vigilance
was the price of safety;- When Visiting Havana
in 1899, I had the pleasure to meet Major Edward O.
Shakespeare, but can not recollect if I have met Major
Walter Reed or Major V. C. Vaughan at that time.
Major Shakespeare informed me of the remarkable
experiments carried out by the Yellow Fever Board,
and we discussed some of my work undertaken
at Pinar del Rio. He held, that no doubt, that
my experiments were of great value in settling
a vexing question at that time, but that my
experiments were, in a measure, based on an
entirely different principal and theory from
those followed by Dr. Carlos Finlay or the Yellow
Fever Board at Havana. My stay at Havana was
very short, and I did not learn at the time all I desired
to know about the exact Modus Operandi of the Yellow Fever Board,
7
7
4.
but Major Shakespeare was kind enough to
keep me ported from time to time.-

Towards fall of 1899, I became fully convinced,
both from personal observation as well as the records
on hands, that Sanarelli serum was a failure
as a prophylactic as well as a curative measure,
and that Bacilus ichtheroides was not the agent
or cause producing Yellow Fever. I was convinced,
that the Mosquito carrier theory was correct, that
the experiments of Major Reed and his Associates
were in the right direction, and that my own work,
while useful in a way, was based on a wrong
supposition.- Half sick, tired, worn out from
constant petty annoyances, I obtained through
your kindness on Sept 12' 1899, one month
leave of absence and returned to the States with
the Depot Battalion of the 1st U. S. Infantry.
On the date of my departure my report showed
that there was not a single case of Yellow fever
in the 1st Military District of Pinar del Rio, but
that there were two cases of Small Pox at Colona
among the natives. - Arriving at my home in
Kansas, the Governor honored me by an appointment
as a Delegate to the Convention of the Association
of Military Surgeons of the U. S. at Kansas City Mo.
While there on Sept 29-1899, during the morning session,
I listened to the paper and discussion of Colonel
Zacarias R. Molina of Mexico - on
8
"Observation upon Yellow Fever or Black Vomit
in the City of Vera Cruz, Mexico, - He conveyed
the idea, that at certain seasons when ships in
the harbor of Vera Cruz, stirred up the mud
at the bottom of the bay, invariably an epidemic
of yellow fever followed. Also he held, that
possibly the microscopic fungus Perosnapara
lutea, was the causative agent, as its stained
everything yellow, but admitted also, that so far
as he knew, no substance was discovered, chemical
or in laboratory or in the human body, which had
the power to destroy or neutralize Yellow Fever.
He stated also, that the elements producing the fever,
whether Micro or Zoosporic were neither contagious
or conveyable, and that the true cause was entirely
unknown up to date. Imagine his surprise when
he learned for the first time of the wonderful
and conclusive experiments by Major Walter Reed
and his Associates in Cuba,- On the same afternoon
I had the pleasure to surrender to Colonel C H. Alden,
the Assistant Surgeon General U. S. Army, in the
presence of my old Chief of the 2d Army Corp,
Colonel A. C. Girard, all the records and finding
I brought with me from Pinar del Rio, made there
in connection with my tests and experiments
with Sanarelli serum, and with it, my personal
conclusions, that I held, that this serum was of
9
5
no practical utility as a curative or a
prophylactic agent against yellow fever, and
that in my opinion the Bacillus ichtheroides
was not its causative agent.-

This terminated my Yellow Fever work in Cuba,
for after expiration of my leave of absence,
I was not permitted to return to Cuba, but
was instead transferred for duty in the Philippine
Islands, while in Manila, at a later date
I learned through friends, that many of my so called
precautionery measures in Pinar del Rio, were
allowed to go into disuse, and that ultimately
yellow Fever broke out among our command there
with disastrous results. And now, allow me
just a short word as to the Medical men, who so faithfully
labored in the cause for the wellfare of humanity in Cuba & the P.
A Reunion of the Spanish War Veterans is to take place this
fall in Havana, Cuba. Do you think, will it possible for our
Great Country to recognice at this time the service rendered by the
last survivor of the Famous Yellow Fever Board, the Dr. Aristides
Agramonte? I feel, that at least a Distinguished Service Medal
ought to be presented to him during the coming Reunion. Also,
I have often wondered, why so few Medical Officers, Regulars or
Volunteers have been recognized and honored for their valuable
service rendered, both in Cuba and the Philippine Islands?-
I wonder why? Must close,- this is getting too long.-
